The generally prevailing interest
in the recently announced policies
of the Athletic Board, and the likelihood that a mass meeting will be
called ill the near future to consider them, have persUaded THE
NEWS-LETTER that intelligent discussion might be fostered by a
knowledge of the conditions which
exist at other colleges in the country; and to promote that knowledge, letters of inquiry were written to Harvard, Yale, Princeton,
and Cornell. Answers have been
received from Princeton and Cornell, the results of which are presented below.
At Princeton all undergraduates
are members of the Athletic Association, which elects the directors
(manager, assistant manager, and
captain) of the various teams.
These directors, together with the
Director of Athletics, who, however, has no vote, constitute the
Executive Committee—a body corresponding in a general way to our
Athletic Board. To quote from the
constitution :
The Executive Committee shall
settle all questions pertaining to any
or all of the athletic organizati
ons
which are not provided for by
the
constitutions of those organizations.
It shall be the duty of the Executive
Committee to consult thc Director of
Athletics and the Graduate Advisory
Committee on all questions of importance.
It shall be the duty of the Executive
Committee to elect the members of the
Graduate Advisory Committee (a body
consisting of five alumni) which can
veto the election of any team captain
or any change contemplated by
the
Athletic Association that involves
alterations in the athletic grounds.

There is a Director of Athletics,
annually, and receiving a
fixed salary, who selects all coachers, passes upon the eligibility of
players, and settles disputes between coachers and captains. There
is also a faculty committee which
prescribes the ordinary eligibility
rules and passes upon all proposed
schedules of games.
At Cornell "Athletic policy and
finances are governed by a council
in which the undergraduate representatives have a majority." For
each team there is an advisory
committee consisting of the captain,
the manager, and a faculty representative. "We have found that
our organization in which the students shape the policies is very
satisfactory," writes Arthur • Gordon, assistant graduate. manager.

Towels at Homewood.

During the past winter several
improvements have ,been made
around the University in the way
of sanitary towels and in having
the comfort rooms painted and refitted to a certain extent. While
the authorities are about it, there
is another improvement that might
well be made and which there is
still time to make.
At present a great many students
pay $1.50 per annum for clean
towels. By .the first of April,
punctually, everybody begins taking exercise out at Homewood instead of in the cage. Under the
present -obnoxious -system,- men who
are not regular members of a
"Varsity, squad must go without
towels '-at Homewood unless they
bring .them themselves; and if this
were not bad enough, the team
managers have to pay from twentyfive cents to fifty cents a dozen to
colored men to carry suitcases of
towels out to the field for the team
members.
All this bother is certainly unnecessary, and may be obviated in
a very simple manner. The towel
companies are of course just as
willing to deliver the towels at
Homewood as at the cage, and as
the "new policies" now require that
no Man may have a key at Homewood, but that the lockers shall be
unlocked by a man who has to stay
there all afternoon for that purpose, why shouldn't he also be
intrusted with the distribution of
towels.
. We should therefore like to suggest to the director of the gymnasium that this matter be arranged so

present system. It is only a square
deal for the men Niiho have paid

protest against the new athletic dictatorship, I think the students
ought, nevertheless, to make a protest. The important matter, to my
mind, is not how much or how
little power the faculty dr the alumexercise over athletic matters,
but rather how, far the students
feel that .their athletic efforts are
spontaneous and natural—how far
they think of them as• play and not
as work. How can any. undergraduate read the recent pronunciaMento from the Athletic Board and
not feel impressed by the tremendous intricacy of trying to have a
eollege team of any character, with
its. inanagerships and sub-manager• ships and super-managershipS? And
must he not feel that the right to
think about athletic matters has
been taken from him for his oWti

that. be? Of what use is his dear

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

great state affairs, but there is a
Pew athletic policy much discussed
in the columns of your paper which
Should like to say a word or two

Management of athletics is to put
tD death a movement originated

years by them. There are and
have been many crushing blows to
the original spirit of college athletics. The latest example is that

The undergraduate .manager has
been reduced to a bat chaser on the
baseball team, and corresponding
positions on the other teams. He
is stripped of his responsibility and
any chance to put personality into
his work, or to "make good." The
absolute heads are the controllers

become a business organization for

press agents. The primary objects
of student athletics are fast becoming old fashioned. The pleasure and

Let us try to get away from the
business or professional spirit now
threatening our great activity. But,
above all things, let us render to
Cesar what is his with respect to

The announcements of the courses
to be given in the second session
of the Hopkins summer school
have been ready for distribution
for the last 1,veek. The purpose of
the school is to give to teachers
instruction in their several lines of
work, and in education; to give
matriculated students an opportunity to gain advanced standing or
to make up conditions; to help unmatriculated students to meet the
requirements for admission; and
to furnish instruction for anyone
else who shOws his ability to profit
by such instruction. For the satisfactory completion of any course
which is regularly given at Hopkins a credit of one-third a course
will be allowed to Hopkins students, but not more than two
courses may be offered for credit.
Although some new courses have
been added, the scope of the school
is essentially like that of last year.
Professor Hodge of Clark University, who initiated "The Killing
Time" in the fly world last year,
Will again teach courses in biology.
Prof. Givler will teach botany and
zoology. Dr. Gilpin besides giving
the standard courses in chemistry,
Will give one course in household
chemistry. The two courses in domestic science will be in charge of
Miss Harris, of public School No.
79. Dr. Buchner has arranged to
have the following courses in education conducted: History of Education, Educational Psychology,
Administration of Public Education, several courses about the eleMentary school, and School Hygiene.
Mr. North, of the Baltimore
Polytechnic Institute., will give a
first course in English composition
and in the teaching of English, and
Professor Gay, of Goucher, will
give more advanced courses. Dr.
barnwell, professor of English,
University of Alabama, will give
the courses in English literature.

nd Lee University, and Professor
v os, of Indiana University, will

fessor Sioussat, of Vanderbilt University, has added a course, The

the two he gave last year.

courses.
All those who wish to study
Music can do so at the summer
school of the Peabody Conservatory of Music.
Mr. Thomas R. Ball, registrar of
the summer school, will be glad to
furnish any further information
desired.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

protest against the new athletic dictatorship, I think the students
ought, nevertheless, to make a protest. The important matter, to my
mind, is not how much or how
little power the faculty dr the alumexercise over athletic matters,
but rather how, far the students
feel that .their athletic efforts are
spontaneous and natural—how far
they think of them as• play and not
as work. How can any. undergraduate read the recent pronunciaMento from the Athletic Board and
not feel impressed by the tremendous intricacy of trying to have a
eollege team of any character, with
its. inanagerships and sub-manager• ships and super-managershipS? And

think about athletic matters has
been taken from him for his oWti
• good, to. be exeiCised with benevolent paternalism by the director of

his . much - amended constitution?

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

have never been desirous Of critiCiSing or even raising my humble
voice above a whisper in any of the
great state affairs, but there is a
Pew athletic policy much discussed
in the columns of your paper which
Should like to say a word or two

gods upon my head. I am making
an appeal in good faith—as an evidence of this I am signing my name

To take away student control and
Management of athletics is to put
tD death a movement originated
zud maintained for a number of

years by them. There are and
have been many crushing blows to
the original spirit of college athletics. The latest example is that
of our new managership policy.
The undergraduate .manager has
been reduced to a bat chaser on the
baseball team, and corresponding
positions on the other teams. He
is stripped of his responsibility and
any chance to put personality into
his work, or to "make good." The
absolute heads are the controllers
and the Athletic Association has
become a business organization for
the promotion of business ends,

salaries of managers, coaches and
press agents. The primary objects
of student athletics are fast becoming old fashioned. The pleasure and
enjoyment of sport, physical development and health are all sacrifices to the business end of the
thing. At last the last vestage of
student control has slipped from
us—the managers are no longer our
own.
What I mean is evidenced by the
rules lately laid down by the Athletic Board. Upon reading the
rules we find phrases such as these:
"He (the undergraduate manager)
should have control, under the direction of the graduate manager,

graduate manager) should make all
final schedules and terms under the
direction of the director of the gymnasium, and should have authority

agent idea set forth again, despite

undergraduate ma na ger s nor

undergraduate manager)should not
be connected with the business management of any college publication
(or any student activity?)." "No
• theatre parties should be given to
a team until after the season, etc.,"
ad infinitum.
Let us create a better ideal in
our athletics than those suggested
by our new policy, and get closer
to the true spirit of the movement.
Let us try to get away from the
business or professional spirit now
threatening our great activity. But,
above all things, let us render to
Cesar what is his with respect to
the government by the .whole.
